Dialogue.Line: Our most basic common link is that we all inhabit this small planet. We all breathe the same air. We all cherish our children's future.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We pull out from the Earth and other languages and voices take over the narration.

Dialogue.Line: I have a dream that one day this nation will rise up

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We reach a massive spaceship.

In Shoreditch in the City of London is a Secondary School, here played by St Johns Church of England School, Hammersmith. An elegant woman in a two piece suit walks round the corner and past a pair of boys kicking a football between them next to a black van. The rest of the pupils are entering the schoolyard but one small blonde girl comes out to watch the scene. The Tardis is parked by a block of flats. The Doctor is walking with Ace, who is carrying a 'ghetto-blaster' on her shoulder, blaring out rock music.

Dialogue.Line: What's she staring at?
Your clothing's a little anachronistic for this time period, and that doesn't help.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor switches off Ace's music.

Dialogue.Line: Well, it's not my fault this decade's got no street cred. I mean, look at that kid.
Strange.
Oi, Professor, can we get something to eat now?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at the doors to the back of the black van. An aerial rotates on the roof and there is a distinct humming.

Dialogue.Line: You're not carrying any Nitro Nine explosives in there?
No.
What do you make of that van?
Dunno. TV detector van?
No. Wrong type of aerial. For this time period, that's a very sophisticated piece of equipment.
What's so sophisticated about that rig? I've seen better aerials on a CB. Professor, I'm hungry. Lack of food makes me hungry, you know.

Lack of food makes you obstreperous. Why don't you go and buy some consumables? There's a cafe down there. While I undertake a detailed and scientific examination of that van that has so singularly failed to grab your attention.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace walks away.

Dialogue.Line: Ace!
What?
Money.
Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds out a small pouch. Ace takes it.

Dialogue.Line: Thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace leaves as the girl watches the Doctor examine the van. 'Return to Sender' is playing in the cafe as Ace enters and a young man in a flying jacket watches her put down the ghetto-blaster and take off her rucksack. He is reading the Daily Mirror with the headline - Give Your Passport To Police. Ace goes to the jukebox. The Doctor climbs up the external ladder to the van roof and uses his umbrella to measure the length of the moving aerial. The little girl goes inside the schoolyard.
Ace hits an ashtray with a knife while the Beatles regale us with 'Do You Want To Know A Secret?'

Dialogue.Line: Service! Oi, anybody home?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The young man in the corner speaks.

Dialogue.Line: Not like that.
Like what, then?
Like this. Oi, Harry! Customer! Like that.
Right.
Coming.
See? It's easy when you know how.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Harry appears from the kitchen area. The menu is priced in shillings and pence, and the calendar on the wall is November 1963.

Dialogue.Line: Right, give it a rest, Mike. I had enough of that during the war. Er, can I help you, Miss?
Oh, yeah. Four bacon sandwiches and a cup of coffee, please.
Four bacon sandwiches and a cup of coffee. Righty-o.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace tips her pre-decimal coins onto the counter and stares at them, baffled.
The Doctor enters. The little girl is playing hopscotch by herself in the middle of four dark patches in the tarmac.

Dialogue.Line: Five six seven eight, it's a doc

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tastes the residue of the nearest patch and goes to the girl, who runs off.

Dialogue.Line: She doesn't talk to strangers. Very wise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at the hopscotch markers and uses a small abacus before smiling and leaving. The girl is standing by the Boys entrance.

Dialogue.Line: Five, six, seven eight. It's a doctor at the gate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves the school by the old Girls gate and runs across the road. He gets into the black van.

Dialogue.Line: Hmm, you took your time. Get on the radio and tell the Group Captain. I think I've located

Dialogue.Stage Direction: This is the woman in the two piece suit. She finally looks at the Doctor, who is examining her monitoring equipment.

Dialogue.Line: The source of magnetic fluctuation, perhaps.
A rhythmically pulsed fluctuation, yes.
I thought so. Any possibility of natural phenomena?
Not likely. It's a repeated sequence.
So, it's artificial in origin.
Yes. Excuse me?
Yes?
Who are you?
The Doctor.
I'm Rachel. Professor Rachel Jensen.
How do you do? I'm sure I've heard of you.
Red Four, Red Four, come in please.
Red Four receiving. Listen, Group Captain, there's this man. What? On my way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace and Mike are walking along past the block of flats.

Dialogue.Line: Twelve pennies to the shilling, eight shillings to the pound right?
No, twenty shillings to the pound. That makes two hundred and forty pennies in a pound. Where are you from anyway?
Perivale. Why? Oh, this is a stupid system. Twelve pennies to the shilling, twenty shillings to the pound, right?
Yeah. Are you from somewhere else?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They walk past the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: No. So what's half a crown?
Well that's easy
Sergeant!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike runs off.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant?
The Group Captain says he's under attack. We have to get moving.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike goes to drive the van. The Doctor pops his head out of the back doors.

Dialogue.Line: Ace, get in here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace gets in the back and Rachel joins Mike up front.

Dialogue.Line: Matthews is hurt.
Where are they?
At the secondary source, Totters Lane.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: I M Forman, Scrap Merchant, 76 Totters Lane says the painting on the big gates where a crowd of locals has gathered. The place where the whole Who saga began is being played by Kew Bridge Steam Museum. A blanket is put over the face of a fallen soldier by Group Captain Gilmore then he goes to meet the van which has been stopped by policeman.

Dialogue.Line: Everyone say Hi! to the handsome, posh Simon Williams.)
Military.
Fine, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The policeman signals and Mike sounds the van's horn. They drive through the crowd into the yard proper. Everyone gets out of the van.

Dialogue.Line: What's the situation?
Who the devil are you?
I'm the Doctor and this is Ace. You must be with the military.
Well, how do you know?
I'm very perceptive.
Is he with you, Professor?
Yes.
Smith.
Sir?
Take the girl and set up a position by Red Six.
Yes, sir. Come on, Ace.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike and Ace leave.

Dialogue.Line: You'd better come and take a look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uncovers Matthews and unfastens his tunic to check his torso.

Dialogue.Line: No evidence of tissue damage. Ah, massive internal displacement.
What?
His insides were scrambled. Very nasty.
The effect of the blast?
No. A projected energy weapon.
Projected what?
A death ray?
Very succinct. I presume you've got reinforcements coming?
Any minute now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes cover behind some metal object.

Dialogue.Line: This is preposterous. A death ray? It's unbelievable.
What a predictable response.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace and Mike go to a black van with no aerial on the roof.

Dialogue.Line: Miss Williams? Allison!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A blond woman wearing a striped university scarf appears.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant, you're here at last. How's Matthews?
He's dead. Is Blue One responding?
What? Blue One? Yes, they'll be here in a minute. Dead, are you sure?
Whatever fired that weapon's trapped in there. There's no way out.
How can you be sure?
I've been here before.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An army lorry drives in carrying a bunch of squaddies.

Dialogue.Line: Right, everybody out! Come on, quickly. Move it, move it. Squad, attention!

Stand at ease. Right, now the situation is this. we have an armed hostile pegged up in that lean-to shed. I want the squad to cover the entrance. No firing unless I give the command. Is that understood?
Yes, sir.
Remember, he's armed and hostile, so keep under cover as much as possible. Sergeant.
Sir.
Detail some men to clear these civilians.
Yes, sir. You two, come down with me and we'll sort this lot out. Now, let's have you all back as far as possible, please. Thank you, madam. There's nothing to be seen here.
Smith.
Yes, sir?
Take two men and get Matthews out of here.
Yes, sir. You two, fall out and follow me.
I don't think you realise what you're dealing with here.
Doctor, I assure you these men are hand picked. They can deal with anything, provided they can see it. Right men, take up positions.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor joins Ace and Allison at Red 6 while Mike and the soldiers recover Matthews.

Dialogue.Line: Take his arms. Move him back to the truck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something targets one of the soldiers and zaps him. There is a brief flash of his skeleton as he is flung back against some corrugated iron sheeting.

Dialogue.Line: Down!
Covering fire now!

Dialogue.Character: (Gilmore and the soldiers take up positions round and under the army lorry and send short bursts of bullets into the shed. GILMORE
Dialogue.Line: Cease firing!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Rachel run over to Gilmore.

Dialogue.Line: Get down!
What was it?
That was your death ray.
I know that, but how? To transmit focused energy at that level, it's incredible. It's
Yes?
It's beyond the realm of current technology.
If you can save the science lecture for a less precipitous moment. Now perhaps, Doctor, you could tell me what is going on?
You must pull your men back now. It's their only chance.
It's preposterous. We can't disengage now. Whoever is in there, my men can handle it. Sergeant!
Listen to me, Brigadier.
Group Captain. Group Captain Gilmore!
Nothing you possess will be effective against what's in there!
Sir?
Three men, rifle-grenades, even spread left right and centre. Fire on my command.
Yes, sir.
Captain, you're not dealing with human beings here.
What am I dealing with? Little green men?
No, Little green blobs in bonded-polycarbite armour.
Grenades are ready, sir.
Group Captain Gilmore.
Fire.
Humans.
Fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: KaBOOM and the shed is obliterated in a fireball. Ace joins the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: That's some serious hardware. Did you see that, Professor? Unsophisticated, but impressive.
Smith!
Sir?
Get on the radio. Call up Blue Four and Six. Tell Four to pick up an ambulance on the way.
Yes, sir.
It doesn't matter how many men you get here. It isn't going to make any difference.
Doctor, my men have just put three high-explosive grenades into a confined area. Nothing even remotely human could have survived that.
That's the point group, Group Captain, it isn't even remotely human.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike gets inside the van and uses a field telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Blue Four, Blue Four, this is Red Six. Come in, please.
Red Six, receiving.
Blue Four. Group Captain Gilmore requests that you pick up an ambulance and proceed to Bravo Delta.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The alien targets Mike in the van, but he moves at the last moment and it misses, going straight through the cab and knocking a bunch of steel drums over.
The soldiers start firing again as Mike scrambles out of the van and joins in.

Dialogue.Line: Cease firing! Cease firing! Wait for a target!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A seriously annoyed oversized pepperpot trundles out, burning round its base.

Dialogue.Line: Fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldiers start shooting, so the Dalek fires back, killing at least one more soldier.

Dialogue.Line: Aim for the eyepiece! Ace, give me some of that Nitro Nine that you're not carrying. Quickly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace hands over a can.

Dialogue.Line: And another.
It's my last can.
I should hope so, too. Er, how long, the fuse?
Ten seconds.
That's long enough.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor makes his way towards the Dalek, keeping under cover.

Dialogue.Line: When I tell you, head for the entrance. Take the girl with you.
Then what?
I'll meet you back at HQ. Go now, Rachel!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace and Rachel leave. The Doctor runs behind some barrels level with the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Oi, Dalek! It's me, the Doctor. What's the matter? Don't you recognise your mortal enemy?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek reverses to turn and approach the Doctor, who takes the tops of the cans and puts them by a stack of bricks.

Dialogue.Line: Three, four, five, six.

Dialogue.Line: Smith!
Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace runs to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Ace, you said ten seconds.
Nobody's perfect, Professor. Are you all right?
Yes, of course I am. Can you drive?
Why?
Good, I thought so. Get in there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ace get into a black van as everyone else comes over to investigate their enemy.

Dialogue.Line: I want an emergency team here at the double. Put a guard on that thing. Inform command HQ we will be returning there at once. And I want a weapons team at the Coal Hill School.
Sir.
And, Smith? I want them armed with ATRs.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rachel uses a pencil to examine the steaming green gunk.

Dialogue.Line: It has an organic content.
Or an occupant.

A Dalek. Only trouble is, it's the wrong Dalek.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace tries to start the van's engine.

Dialogue.Line: Would the right one be better or worse?
Yes. Choke.
No, thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls out the choke, freeing more fuel into the engine. Gosh, I remember having to do that.

Dialogue.Line: What do you think you're doing?
Borrowing your van.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They drive out of the yard, only hitting one barrel.

Dialogue.Line: These Day-leks
Daleks.
Oh, Daleks. Where are they from?
From Skaro. At least, originally. They're the mutated remains of a species called the Kaleds. Left here.
When were they left here?
No. Turn left here.
Oh, right.
No, left! You've missed the turning.
What turn? Where?
Why don't you concentrate on where you're going?
Look, I'm doing the best I can. If you don't like it, you drive.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They drive under a railway arch and suddenly the Doctor and Ace have swapped places.

Dialogue.Line: The Kaleds were at war with the Thals. They had a dirty nuclear war. The resulting mutations were then accelerated by their chief scientist, Davros. What he created them he then placed them in a metal war machine, and that's how the Daleks came about
So that metal thing had a creature inside controlling it?
Exactly. And ever since the Daleks were created, they've tried to conquer and enslave as much as the universe as they can get their grubby protuberances on.
And now they want to conquer the Earth.
Nothing so mundane. They conquer the Earth in the 22nd century. No. They want the Hand of Omega.
What's that?
One thing at a time, Ace.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gilmore enters the Territorial Army Centre at Acton and meets Mike in the corridor. Somewhere there is typing being done.

Dialogue.Line: Sir?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A smartly dressed man with old school tie.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry, sir. This is Mister Ratcliffe. He's brought some of his men, I think they can be of some use to us.
You do, do you? Mister Ratcliffe.

Dialogue.Line: Please to meet you, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone say Hi! to tough guy George Sewell.

Dialogue.Line: We must get that Dalek to a well-equipped laboratory.
And a half decent biologist.

Before I make any suggestions I want to catch up with the Doctor.

Someone who knows a lot more about Daleks then we do. When I get hold of him, I'm going to get some answers out of him or

He certainly seems to have a detailed knowledge of the Daleks, and given that they are not terrestrial, it is possible that he is
Not of this Earth? An alien?

Good afternoon.

The Doctor. And you?

References?

Oh. What can I do for you, then?
Well, we would like to look round your school, if you don't mind?
I'm afraid that's out of the question.

You'll have to be a bit more specific, Doctor.

My pleasure.
Smith.
Sir?

Red Four has been seen in the Coal Hill area, sir.
He must be heading back to the school.

What do you make of that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the window.

The burn marks. See them? Well?
A landing pattern for some kind of spacecraft, isn't it?

Yes.

Dialogue.Line: Report.

That is to be expected. I must be informed of his movements.
Yes, yes. We have our contacts. I shall see that he is followed. That Dalek machine.
Yes?

A machine, a tool. Nothing more.

Shush. Whoever it was landed the spaceship in the playground.
And that would be?
More Daleks.
Oh, great. I thought it might be something really nasty.
Ah, the cellar. It could be down in there.

Good place to put things, cellars.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Headmaster observes them.

So do I.

The unknown.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes an aluminium baseball bat from her rucksack and holds it ready. They get to the bottom of the steps and discover a transmat platform, flashing.

Yes. Very elegant, very advanced. Flux circuitry elements.

Professor? Professor, something's activating it.
Very likely. It has an automatic activator. What? You're right. Something is beginning to come through.
It's another Dalek.
Excellent.
Will this one be friendly?
I sincerely doubt that. If I can just get the transmitter to de-phase at the critical point.
Doctor!
Any moment now. Quick! Down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek is nearly solid when it disappears in a swirl.

Dialogue.Line: The controls have gone dead.
Yes, the de-phase must have caused an overload.
What did you do to it?

Well, I persuaded one half of the Dalek to materialise where its other half was materialising. The two halves tried to co-exist at the same point. The resulting reaction destroyed it. Dangerous things, transmats.
So no more Daleks can be transported through here?
Well, it'll slow them down a bit until the operator can repair the systems.
The operator?
Yes, the Daleks usually leave an operator on station in case of any malfunctions.
And that would be another Dalek?
Yes.
Stay where you are! Do not move!
The stairs!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace gets to the top of the stairs first and bumps into the Headmaster.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, sorry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Headmaster knocks out Ace and bolts the door closed.

Dialogue.Line: Ace! Ace! Open the door! Ace! Open

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace wakes up and attacks the Headmaster. He goes down easily and she unbolts the cellar door.

Dialogue.Line: Exterminate! Exterminate!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor falls backwards into the corridor and Ace bolts the door shut in the Dalek's face.

Dialogue.Line: Exterminate!
Doctor!
What's the matter with him?
Stomach ace.
School dinners. Give me a hand.
Professor, he tried to lock you in.
Ace!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They drag the Headmaster away from the door, and the Doctor finds some electronics implanted behind the Headmaster's left ear. The Doctor and Ace run out of the school just before the Dalek blasts the cellar door down.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry.
We must repair the transmat.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An RAF Land Rover is parked up outside. You can tell by the roundel.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing here? Oh, never mind. Get this thing out of here.

ATRs. Anti-tank rockets.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ace run round the back and open the canvas cover.

Dialogue.Line: Will these things be any good against the Daleks?
It's not the Daleks we're after, it's the transmat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As usual it isn't the Dalek getting its sink-plunger dirty with actual work.

Dialogue.Line: You will remain here.
You'll have to sign for them, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor signs with a question mark then attempts to pocket the soldier's pen.

Dialogue.Line: Ahem.
Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ace leave with weaponry. The airman starts to close up the back of the Land Rover when the little blond girl appears.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, love.
What about the Dalek? Won't he try and stop us?

Hey. It must have gone back down to the cellar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wrong.

Dialogue.Line: You will be exterminated.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek fires and misses. The Doctor overturns a table as a barricade.

Dialogue.Line: Ace, get down!
Exterminate!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The trophy cabinet is destroyed. Ace uses the anti-tank rocket. KaBOOM goes the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Ace.
You destroyed it.
I aimed for the eye-piece.
This way! Move it, move it! You fetch the Group Captain. Any more?
No.
Did you do that?
It makes a lot of smoke, doesn't it.
Yeah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gilmore runs in.

Dialogue.Line: You've destroyed it. Good.
It is not good. Nothing about this is good. I've made a grave error of judgment. Oh, I'm going to wish I'd never started all this. Group Captain, I must ask you to evacuate the immediate area.
That's an absurd idea.
Why, Doctor?
I've reason to believe a major Dalek Task Force could soon be operating here.
Great.
And where will this Task Force arrive from?
One certainly is in place hidden somewhere in this vicinity. The other probably from a mothership in geostationary orbit.
Be reasonable, Doctor.
Do you doubt the non-terrestrial nature of the Daleks? I mean, examine this one. Or better still, ask your Scientific Advisor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves them with the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Professor?
I'm afraid the Doctor's right. It is alien.
You're positive?
Yes.
Professor, a word. This Doctor, do you trust him?
Well, he knows what he's talking about, and considerably more than he's telling us. I think we should go along with him for now.
And later?
We could ask him for an explanation.
We could do a lot more than ask. Very well, Doctor. I'll have to get a decision about this evacuation from my superiors.
Splendid.
I should know either way by tomorrow morning. I'll see you all then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gilmore leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I shouldn't touch it if I were you. It may not be completely dormant yet.
That stench.
Now, Doctor, I have questions I would like answered.
So have I. I'll return in the morning.
Doctor, where are you going?
To bury the past.
I'm coming with you.
It is not your past. You haven't been born yet. Would someone look after Ace for me?
Yes, of course.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes her baseball bat.

Dialogue.Line: I'll borrow this.
Sergeant, have you room for Ace at your house?
Yeah, sure. Mum runs a boarding house. I'd like you to meet her.
Ace?
Yes?
Not been born yet. What did he mean by that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace just smiles.
The sign says open, but there are no lights on and no customers. A Jamaican man comes out from the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: Can I help you?
A mug of tea, please.
Cold night tonight.
Yes, it is. Bitter, very bitter. Where's Harry?
Visiting his missus. She's in hospital.
Of course. It'll be twins.
Hmm? Your tea. Sugar?
Ah. A decision. Would it make any difference?
It would make your tea sweet.
Yes, but beyond the confines of my tastebuds, would it make any difference?
Not really.
But
Yeah?
What if I could control people's tastebuds? What if I decided that no one would take sugar? That'd make a difference to those who sell the sugar and those that cut the cane.
My father, he was a cane cutter.
Exactly. Now, if no one had used sugar, your father wouldn't have been a cane cutter.
If this sugar thing had never started, my great-grandfather wouldn't have been kidnapped, chained up, and sold in Kingston in the first place. I'd be a African.

See? Every great decision creates ripples, like a huge boulder dropped in a lake. The ripples merge, rebound off the banks in unforeseeable ways. The heavier the decision, the larger the waves, the more uncertain the consequences.
Life's like that. Best thing is just to get on with it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little girl looks in the window at them, and leaves as the Doctor notices her.

Dialogue.Line: Did you see that?
See what?
Nothing. What would you do if you had a decision, a big decision?
How big?
Saving the world.
Really?
Really.
I wish you the best of luck.
Let's hope I make the right decision. Things could get unpleasant round here. I'd take a holiday if I were you.
Oh, sure. How long?
Two or three days. After that, it won't matter one way or the other. Thanks for the tea.
Any time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts a coin on the counter and leaves. John picks it up.

Dialogue.Line: Nineteen ninety one?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Back at the school, a soldier armed with an ATR leaves the cellar just before the transmat starts up and delivers another cream and silver Dalek.

Next morning, as the milkman leaves a pint at the front door, in the back a Welshman is screwing the brass fittings onto a coffin. Something crackles in a large casket of bizarre design nearby. He goes to it and gets a small static electric shock.

Dialogue.Line: Good morning. I believe this belongs to you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands over the bottle of milk.

Dialogue.Line: Yes.
The door was open so I thought I'd just pop in and collect my casket.
Ah, well, I'm the governor has yet to arrive and I'm afraid I can't just let you. Which er, casket would this be?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes out Ace's baseball bat and indicates the strange one.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I see. Er, well, if you could just wait until the governor arrives, I'm sure
Yes, that would be perfectly all right.
Oh, good. Splendid. Mister er
Doctor.
Doctor?
Yes. Now, if I might be alone with the
Oh, yes, yes, of course. I'll leave you alone with, er.
Thank you.
I'll just be in the next room if you
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Martin leaves. The Doctor shuts the door behind him then returns to the casket.

Dialogue.Line: Hello. Open.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The casket lid tilts open to reveal dry ice swirling around inside.
Martin is on the phone to his boss.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, governor? Somebody's come to collect that big casket. Yes. Yes, the Doctor. Just one thing, governor. I thought you said he was an old geezer with white hair.
Now, let's see what you can make of this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor places the baseball bat on the dry ice and it slowly sinks.
In the boarding house. Mike is fully dressed when Ace enters in a dressing gown.

Dialogue.Line: Hello.
Good morning.
Where are you off to?
I have to check some things out at the Association.
Who's the Association?
They're my friends. You can meet them later.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike leaves. Ace picks up the newspaper - Daily Express with headline Rescue Bid Is On.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, now. Give it up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The baseball bat zooms up and the Doctor grabs it.

Dialogue.Line: Goodbye. Close.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The casket lid shuts.

Dialogue.Line: Follow me.
Yes, all right, governor.
Thank you.
Oh, cheerio, Doctor. But Doctor, what about your

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The casket glides past Martin, who faints.

Dialogue.Line: Once we possess this Hand of Omega, what then?
We shall be on the brink of great power.
And our agreement?
You too shall share this power, if you have the stomach for it.
What do you mean?
There will be casualties. Many deaths.
War is hell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The funeral procession is the Doctor and a vicar using a white stick, with the casket bringing up the rear.

Dialogue.Line: It's very good of you to do this at such short notice.
Nonsense, my dear Doctor. The grave's been ready for a month. Mister Stevens, the gravedigger, was wondering what he should do.
I had to leave suddenly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They turn off the path to an open grave. The casket positions itself over the hole in the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Forgive me for saying this, but it seems to me that your voice has changed somewhat since we last met.
Yes, it has changed. Several times.
I must say your pallbearers are very quiet. Silent as ghosts, really.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor removes his hat.
Ratcliffe is pacing when the telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Yes? Good. Stay with the Doctor. Watch him and call me back. Ah, ah, ah. Yours not to reason why, just to obey orders. Now just get on with it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts the telephone down.

Dialogue.Line: My man has found it.
Yes, but my enemies have found your man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike comes out of a telephone box and walks past the Headmaster, who then gets an instruction via the chip in his head.

Dialogue.Line: He is an agent of the renegade Daleks. Apprehend and interrogate.
I obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Headmaster follows Mike into the cemetery.
The Headmaster grabs Mike from behind.

Dialogue.Line: What is the location of the renegade Dalek base?
What? Get off me or I'll break
What is the location of the renegade Dalek base?
I don't know what you're talking about.
Renegade Daleks have defied the will of the Emperor Dalek. They must be located and destroyed. And you are an agent of the renegade Daleks.
I work for Mister Ratcliffe. The Association.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike finally elbows the Headmaster in the stomach and frees himself.

Dialogue.Line: Who do you work for?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Headmaster stares into the sky.

Dialogue.Line: Alert. Security is compromised. Terminate agent.
No!
Who do you work for?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Headmaster dies. Mike puts him down on an old work memorial stone below an angel monument and runs off. Meanwhile, the casket is lowering itself into the grave.

Dialogue.Line: It is over.
No. It's only just beginning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws a handful of soil onto the casket then gently leads the blind vicar away, watched by Mike.
Mike's mum brings in a fresh pot of tea for her three lady guests.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you.
The Professor said he'd be back by now.
What was he doing, anyway?
Working, unlike some people.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Mike enter.

Dialogue.Line: Have a nice sleep?
It was okay. You're late.
I found him wandering the streets.
I was not wandering the streets. I was merely contemplating certain local cartographic anomalies.
There's a message for you, Mike.
Thanks. Ladies and gentlemen, the Group Captain is expecting us.
Great. Something to do at last.
Ah. He specifically ordered that Ace remain here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike screws up the note to stop Ace reading it.

Dialogue.Line: Professor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has picked up a copy of 'Doctor in the House'.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Ace, I have a present for you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He takes out her baseball bat and taps it against his hand. It sparks and hurts.

Dialogue.Line: How did you do that?
Higher technology, and no, I can't tell you how.
Why not?
You're not ready for it. No one on this planet is.
Ladies? Doctor?
I'll meet you outside.
Sorry, Ace. Work to be done. Back at six. Have dinner ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike, Allison and Rachel leave.

Dialogue.Line: Toe rag. Professor, you can't leave me here.
Ace, I'm trying to convince Group Captain Gilmore to keep his men out of trouble, otherwise there'll be a lot of needless deaths.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike keeps sounding the van's horn outside.

Dialogue.Line: You're up to something.
Yes.
Then I have to come with you.
No.
Who else is going to guard your back?
Will you obey me this once? I'll explain everything when I return.
Tell me now!
I haven't got the time!
All right, I'll stay here if that's what you want.
Trust me.
Doctor?
Yes?
You'd better explain when you get back, or
Or?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace hefts her baseball bat.

Dialogue.Line: Things could get nasty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes into the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: I wonder what he's up to?
Who knows? His motives are alien.
Meaning?
Meaning I don't think he's human.
And Ace?
She's not an alien. You're all right there.
Good. Well, I mean, I wouldn't want her to be foreign, would I?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, here comes the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A second high-tech wall panel is revealed. It shows a map of the local streets with various alien symbols on it.

Dialogue.Line: The enemy is about to start moving.
Do you think that Group Captain Gilmore suspects us?
(scoffs) Not the paltry military forces of your world. The real enemy. The Imperial Dalek faction, may their shells be blighted. Soon it will be war. Are you ready for war, Mister Ratcliffe?
Yes. This country fought for the wrong cause in the last war. When I spoke out, they had me imprisoned.
You will be on the right side in this war.
Group Captain, the evacuation?

I've been in direct contact with High Command and they've agreed to stage a quiet withdrawal under the peace time nuclear accident provisions. They felt that given the sensitive stage of the current government
Just for a change.

They felt, Miss Williams, that the initial stages could be carried out under the aegis of the Counter-Intrusion Measures, United Kingdom. The D-notice office has of course been informed and a cover story prepared.
What is it?
I have no idea. Not my department. Now, Doctor, since you hold my career in your hands, I trust you can justify my faith.
With respect, Group Captain, your career's magnificently irrelevant. Now, let's see. Any more transmission sites?
No, just at the school.
Good. I want a direct line to Jodrell Bank. Let's see. 1963. The Fylingdale installations and the Royal Observatory. Order them to search these localities for any signs of high orbital activity.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike gives the Doctor a pencil to write them down. The Doctor hands the note to him and keeps the pencil, then switches on the light above a pool table covered in maps.

Dialogue.Line: Now, I want the detector vans moved so they can cover this area here and here. Order all air and ground forces to avoid engaging the enemy at all costs. We must act with extreme caution.
And if we don't?
Goodbye civilisation as you know it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mrs Smith is doing some ironing while Ace plaits her hair. She is completely bored now and decides to turn on the small TV set in the corner. It eventually warms up and shows the Test Card while playing music. Mrs Smith leaves the room. Ace finds the notice in the window that says - No Coloureds. She takes it down.

Dialogue.Line: Mrs Smith?
Yes?
I'm just going out for a breath of fresh air.
All right, dear.
This is BBC television. The time is a quarter past five and Saturday viewing continues with an adventure in the new science fiction series, Doc

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But Ace has already left the room.
The teleprinter is chattering away. The Doctor tears off the paper to read it.

Dialogue.Line: Twenty six by zero zero one. A big mothership of some kind, with maybe as many as four hundred Daleks on board. Well, at least we know where it is.
Much good that does us.
It would be foolish of me, I suppose, to hope that this mothership was not nuclear capable?
That ship has weapons capable of cracking open this planet like an egg.
We've got the parts you wanted, Doctor. Where do you want them?
Good. Over here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor clears the maps from the pool table, and Allison and Mike deposit their armfuls of bits and pieces.

Dialogue.Line: Allison, we've located the mothership. It's in a powered geostationary orbit
Where?
Guess.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike looks up at the ceiling.

Dialogue.Line: Right.
Is that their main base, Doctor?
For one group, at least. I believe we're dealing with two antagonistic Dalek factions.
Two?
And do they both come from outer space?
From another planet in a distant future. We must try and contain them, let them destroy each other.
Shouldn't we send for reinforcements? Armoured units?

Have you been listening to me, Group Captain? That spaceship up there has surveillance equipment capable of spotting a sparrow fall at fifteen thousand kilometres. Any sign of a military build-up and they may simply decide to sterilise the area.
And we have no defence.
Frightening, isn't it, to find there are others better versed in death than human beings.
Hello? Anyone at home?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace gives the fallen Dalek a look over then goes up the stairs. Down in the cellar, a fourth Dalek is transmatting in.
Ace turns on her ghetto blaster, but it's not the station she expects to receive.

Dialogue.Line: Attack squad in position. DALEK 2 [OC]: Lower area clear.
Proceed. Exterminate any aliens.
We obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes her baseball bat from her rucksack and turns her player from radio to tape. She goes out to the stairwell to see a cream and gold Dalek on it's way up. She runs and it fires.
The Doctor has built a gizmo with what looks like an infrared light on the end.

Dialogue.Line: What does it do?
Well, at best it will interfere with the Dalek's control systems. I rigged something like it on Spiridon.
And the worst?
It'll do absolutely nothing.
Doctor? Red Nine reports an increase in modulated signalling.
Where?
Just a minute.
Mike, phone up Ace and tell her someone will come and collect her.
Right.
The signal emanates from Coal Hill School. Multiple sources in close proximity.
Multiple? They've got the transmat working again.
Transmat? What does that mean?
More Daleks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gilmore bursts in.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, there's no reply from my men at the school.
Get a vehicle ready. Load it up with plastic explosives and integral detonators.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gilmore leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Why explosives?
Well, that thing merely disorients and weakens them. What do you expect me to do then, talk to them sternly?
Doctor, Mum says that Ace left ages ago.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek has glided slowly to the top of the stairs. Ace hides behind the doors as it enters and blasts her noisy tape player to pieces and reports in.

Dialogue.Line: Small human female sighted on level three.
Who are you calling small?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace starts hitting it with her souped up baseball bat.

Dialogue.Line: Under attack. Under attack.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She knocks off its eyepiece then dives under the benches.

Dialogue.Line: Vision impaired.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It starts firing wildly.

Dialogue.Line: Reinforcements requested.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace leaps through a window into the corridor. A second Dalek has come up the stairs. It fires and misses so she gives it a clout before running down the stairs.
By the entrance is a dead soldier. Ace takes his rifle and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Human female is now leaving building.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs in with his gizmo, followed by Mike and some soldiers.

Dialogue.Line: Exterminate. Exterminate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He turns on the gizmo and it works. The Daleks start groaning.

Dialogue.Line: You, move in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike and two soldiers sticks some explosives on the Daleks and pull the pins on the detonators, as Ace gets out from in between.

Dialogue.Line: Fall back. Fall back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike and the soldiers run outside.

Dialogue.Line: It works. It works!
Fall back! Three, two, one, down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The three Daleks get their heads blown off. Gilmore, Rachel and Allison join the men as they reenter.

Dialogue.Line: There were living beings in there.
Not any more.
Come on, Sergeant. We'll search upstairs.
Yes, sir. Doctor, may I?
Yes, Sergeant.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands over his gizmo.

Dialogue.Line: Right.
Stay sharp. Follow me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The military head out, leaving the scientists behind.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Hmm?
This one's still active.
Oh? Let's see, Professor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A claw comes up from the third Dalek casing and grabs the Doctor round the throat. Allison grabs Ace's abandoned baseball bat and starts hitting it. Finally it lets him go, and she keeps on hitting the squealing thing until it shuts up, and beyond.

Dialogue.Line: Allison, it's dead. Thank you.
What was that?
They've mutated again. Here, come and have a look. Compare that to the destroyed Dalek at Totter's Lane. Note the difference.

The other Dalek was underdeveloped, with vestigial limbs and sensory organs almost amoeboid. Allison, look. This is altogether different. It has functional appendages and some kind of mechanical prosthesis grafted into its very body. I think I'm going to be sick.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Boom.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant Smith must have found some more Daleks.
Don't anyone give me a hand.
Ace, you're hurt.
I had an argument with a window.
You two go down and check the cellar, but don't touch anything. I'll look after Ace.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rachel and Allison leave.

Dialogue.Line: When I say stay put, I mean stay put, not take on an entire Dalek assault squad single-handed. What were you doing here, anyway?
I came to get my tape deck.
Where is it?
It's in little bits.
Good.
Good? Ow. What do you mean, good. Where am I going to get another one?

That tape deck was a dangerous anachronism. If someone had found it and discovered the principles of its function, the whole microchip revolution would take place now, twenty years too early, with incalculable damage to the time line.
So?

So? Ace, the Daleks have a mothership up there capable of eradicating this planet from space, but even they, ruthless though they are, would think twice before making such a radical alteration to the time line. _(The Doctor checks Ace's leg then tweaks her ear.)
There, you ought to be able to get up and walk about now.
Cheers, Professor.
Bridge reporting. Mothership will maintain Earth geostationary orbit. All systems fully operational. Attack squad Delta prepare to enter transmat.
The subject obviously is placed on that dais. Then what?
The Doctor called it a transmat. What's that imply to you?
Matter transmission? But that's impossible.
Impossible. You know, after this is over I'm going to retire and raise begonias.
Lovely flowers, begonias.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters with Ace's baseball bat.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, how exactly does this thing work?
Don't bother.
It's a link for the Daleks, allowing them to beam death squads onto Earth without anybody knowing. And I don't want them here just yet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sets about the transmat with the baseball bat until he breaks it.

Dialogue.Line: Weapons. Always useless in the end. Oh, you look hungry. How about lunch?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ratcliffe marches up to the new grave, which now sports a lovely black marble headstone by A Tomes of Acton, with a lower case Omega in gold.
Lollipop is playing on the jukebox as the whole party is eating.

Dialogue.Line: Professor, what are you doing?
Concentrating.
Harry, I wanted some toast.
Coming, coming.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace goes to Rachel and Allison's table.

Dialogue.Line: May I?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes the spare chair and joins Mike and his friends at their table.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Ace.
Hi.
You've met Paul, John.
Hello.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ratcliffe takes a metal bar from a nearby grave and inserts it into the Omega grave. When it reaches the casket he gets an electric shock that throws him back.

Dialogue.Line: Argh!
Power source detected. Alert! Power source detected. Full alert!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two more second cream and gold Daleks enter.

Dialogue.Line: It is the Hand of Omega. DALEK 3: Inform the Emperor Dalek.
I obey.
I just feel we should be doing something.
Frankly, I wouldn't advise it, Group Captain. We're in way over our heads.
You were hired as a Chief Scientific Advisor. One tends to expect advise from one's advisors.

For one thing, Group Captain, I was not hired, I was drafted. And for another, do you think I am enjoying having some space vagrant come along and tell me that the painstaking research I've devoted my life to has been superceded by a bunch of tin plated pepperpots?
Steady on.

Steady on? You drag me down from Cambridge, you quote the Peace Time Emergency Powers Act at me, and then you expect me to advise on something outside the realm of human experience. Bluntly, Group Captain, we're reliant on the Doctor because only the Doctor knows what is going on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little schoolgirl skips up to Ratcliffe's lorry, parked by the grave. His men are exhuming the casket.

Dialogue.Line: Get on with it. I want that coffin back at the warehouse.
Guv.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ratcliffe goes over to the girl.

Dialogue.Line: What are you staring at?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She looks at the grave, then up at the sky.

Dialogue.Line: Emperor on the bridge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A giant headed Dalek with no eyepiece, sink plunger or weapon rolls up.

Dialogue.Line: Report.
The transmat is no longer operational. DALEK 2: We have established the position of the Omega device.
Prepare the assault shuttle. DALEK 2: Renegade Dalek agents are in the area.
They will surrender the Hand of Omega.
Haven't you got a home to go to? Come on, lads, put your backs into it. We haven't got all day.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: When he looks back, the girl has vanished.

Dialogue.Line: Group Captain, we need to establish a forward base at the school. Can it be done?
Of course.
Thank you for your cooperation.
Only a fool argues with his doctor. Sergeant!
Sir?
Get Embery. Set up a command unit. Forward command on the third floor, defensive positions on the ground floor and the roof. Get a move on.
Yes, sir. All right, men, fall out. Follow me back to the school.
Professor Jensen, Miss Williams, follow me.
Jawohl. Coming, Professor Jensen?
Of course, Miss Williams.
I wish Bernard was here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Professor Bernard Quatermass, that is.

Dialogue.Line: The British Rocket Group's got its own problems.
Harry, toast.
Coming, coming.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just the Doctor and Ace are left in the cafe now.

Dialogue.Line: What's so important about the school?
Well, now that I've disabled the transmat, absolutely nothing. As long as the renegade Daleks have got the Hand of Omega, then the Imperial Daleks' attention will be focused on that.
So there are two sets of Daleks.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ratcliffe and his men drive into the yard with the casket on the back of the lorry. Ratcliffe goes to his office.

Dialogue.Line: We have the Hand of Omega. It's out in the yard.
Excellent.
Good. I'll tell my man. After all, he found it.
Mike? There's a phone call for you in the Headmaster's office.
Thanks.
Professor?
Yes?
If this place is so out of the way of the action, what are we doing here?
Keeping an eye on Group Captain Chunky Gilmore. Although why his men call him Chunky, I've no idea.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They walk past a machine gun emplacement being built out of sandbags.

Dialogue.Line: They're really going for it.
That's the general idea. I want to keep the military fully occupied and out of the way.
Out of the way of what? Oh, Professor, you promised me, remember?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They start up the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: A long time ago, on my home planet of Gallifrey, there lived a stellar engineer called Omega.
Stellar? As in stars? You mean he engineered stars?
Ace!
Sorry. Go on.

It was Omega who created the supernova that was the initial power source for Gallifreyan time travel experiments. He left behind him the basis on which Rassilon founded Time Lord society, and he left behind the Hand of Omega.
His hand? What good was that?
No, no, not his hand literally. No, no, it's called that because Time Lords have an infinite capacity for pretension.
I've noticed that.
The Hand of Omega is a mythical name for Omega's remote stellar manipulator, a device used to customise stars with. And didn't we have trouble with the prototype.
We?
They.
And the Daleks want it so they can recreate the time travel experiments? But you said that both Dalek factions can already travel in time.
Oh yes, Daleks have got time corridor technology, but it's very crude and nasty. What they want is the power that Time Lords have, and they'll get that with the Hand of Omega, or so they think.
And you have to try and stop them.
No, Ace, I want them to have it.
Eh?
My problem is trying to stop Group Captain Gilmore and his men getting diced in the crossfire.
So, all this is
A massive deception, yes.
Oh, well devious. So the Daleks grab the Hand of Omega and go, and no one gets hurt. Brilliant.
Just one thing.
What?
I didn't expect two Dalek factions, and now I've got to make sure the wrong ones don't get their grubby little protuberances on it.
Shouldn't we take Mike?
No. Dalek hunting is a terminal pastime.
So what are we doing?
Dalek hunting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Black Dalek watches Ratcliffe's men take the casket off the lorry and inside.

Dialogue.Line: Advance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grey Daleks follow it.

Dialogue.Line: Stay where you are.

It's been a long and difficult struggle for myself and my men. Now we can afford to relax and reap the rewards. As I said, people need a firm hand. It's in their nature. They feel more comfortable with a strong leader, someone who knows when to be lenient and when to be harsh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dalek weapon fire outside. Ratcliffe rushes out to see his men dying, then runs back in.

Dialogue.Line: What have you done to those men? They were on our side!
You are a slave, Ratcliffe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The controller turns round and remove the helmet.

Dialogue.Line: You were born to serve the Daleks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ratcliffe's jaw hits the floor.

Dialogue.Line: Patrol the area until the time controller is operational.
We obey.
You will obey the Daleks or you will be exterminated. Activate the time controller.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The girl goes to Ratcliffe's desk and opens the bottom drawer. It contains a large globe on a base. She runs her hands over the globe, generating electricity inside it.

Dialogue.Line: Time controller activated. Calculating coordinates.
You will come with us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The grey Daleks trundle down the street as the Doctor and Ace hide behind a parked car.

Dialogue.Line: This way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They dash through a door as another grey Dalek comes out and heads off.

Dialogue.Line: The main staging area must be in that warehouse.
Are we going to have a look?
Might as well.
I've checked the whole building, sir. There's no sign of Ace or the Doctor.
Right, deploy lookouts, take a squad and sweep the area. I want the Doctor found and brought back here.
Yes, sir. Okay, men, follow me.
You two, follow me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rachel and Allison snap to attention and obey.
The Doctor and Ace sneak in and he checks the fallen men.

Dialogue.Line: Daleks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The casket mutters on its pallet. He goes to soothe it.

Dialogue.Line: Be quiet.
Is that it?
The Hand of Omega's inside this box. The most powerful and sophisticated remote stellar control manipulator device ever constructed.
Are you sure you want the Daleks to have it?
Absolutely. You know what you've got to do, don't you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Hand chirps its reply.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, of course you do.
Is it alive?
In a manner of speaking, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek chair is unoccupied.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
Some kind of biomechanoid control system, for a small human. Of course, it's a battle computer!
But why would a human need to sit in it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace sits in the seat and the Doctor pulls her out.

Dialogue.Line: The Dalek's major drawback is their dependency on rationality and logic. The solution? Get a human, preferably young, imaginative, plug the child into the system, and their ingenuity and creativity are slaved to the battle computer.
That's well boggling.
It's obscene. Ah, now for the time controller.
Hey, is this it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slaps Ace's hands off the electrostatic globe.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
It's a device the renegade Daleks use to travel through time. They've come a long way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The globe switches off.

Dialogue.Line: Have you busted it?
No, no, no, I don't want to lumber Earth with a load of desperate Daleks. I've merely put it out of phase. They'll be able to fix it, but it'll slow them down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stretches out his arm and magically produces a calling card, which he puts onto the time controller.

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do to me?
Remain silent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ace run and hide behind a rack in the store room. The girl leads Ratcliffe and the Black Dalek into the office.

Dialogue.Line: The time controller has been disabled!
Instruct all Daleks to seek and destroy the intruder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The girl holds up the Doctor's calling card - Gallifreyan characters, a black seal and a gold question mark.

Dialogue.Line: Exterminate the Doctor! Crush all resistance!
I obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She goes to the battle computer, sits in the seat and pulls the helmet down over her head.
The Doctor and Ace make their escape from the yard and run round the corner to hide behind a workman's hut as a grey Dalek trundles past.

Dialogue.Line: Why didn't you just run off with the Hand of Omega and give it to the other Daleks?
With a bit of luck, the Imperial Daleks will wipe out the renegade faction. Besides, I can't just roll up and give it to them. They get suspicious.
Suspicious of what? You still haven't told me w
Shush!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek returns so they hide inside the canvas hut. The Doctor stifles a sneeze as it circles, then they run off in the direction of the Kings Arms.

Dialogue.Line: All right, follow me and keep your eyes peeled for Ace and the Doctor. Move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ace come running down the street.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, Doctor!
Yes?
Couldn't we just get in
No, no, no, we've got work to do. Anyway, here come the military.
Where've you been?
Dalek hunting. Now it's the other way around. Is Gilmore back at the school?
Yes.
Good. We'll go back and smooth his troubled brow.
Ace, when we're finished with this lot, do you fancy going to the pictures?
You're confident. Why, what's on?
I don't know.
Doesn't matter. I've probably seen it on television anyway.
Huh? Daleks! Move it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They make it back into the school yard just before the grey Dalek opens fire.
The Doctor staggers in, breathless.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Doctor, I trust your little jaunt was successful.
Moderately so. I'm afraid we've brought back some Daleks with us.
I don't get it. They've got the Hand of Omega. Why don't they just leave?
How did you know that, Sergeant?
Ace told me.
You toe rag. You lying dirty scumbag.
It can wait.
You're finished. He's a grass, a dirty stinking grass! He's selling us out to the Daleks!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drags Ace up the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: What's going on, Sergeant? What are they talking about?
I didn't know it was the Daleks, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike is escorted away. Outside, the machine gun nest is under attack. It doesn't last long.
The little girl is still plugged into the battle computer.

Dialogue.Line: Imperial Dalek shuttlecraft entering atmosphere.
We must defend the Hand of Omega. Withdraw all units. Return to base immediately.
I obey.
Battle computer to all units. Withdraw immediately.
Return to base.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The shuttlecraft has planted itself neatly on the existing scorch marks. A hatch opens and a cream and gold Dalek leads its companions out.

Dialogue.Line: Advance. We must capture the Hand of Omega from renegade Dalek faction. Proceed to area two five zero six immediately.
Right, out of here. Everybody downstairs.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rachel, Allison and Ace leave. Gilmore joins the Doctor at the shattered window.

Dialogue.Line: Is that the mothership?
No, that's a shuttle. The mothership's much larger. Are you willing to cooperate with me now?
Do I have a choice?
Well, you could go down there and make a gloriously futile gesture, yes.
What do we do?
A little bit of piracy.
Ace.
Go away.
Ace, I didn't know it was the Daleks. I was just doing Mister Ratcliffe a favour.
Do me a favour and drown yourself.

I thought it was the right thing. Mister Ratcliffe had such great plans. Ace, I never really wanted to hurt anybody. It's just you have to protect your own, keep the outsiders out just that your own people can have a fair chance.
I said shut up! You've betrayed the Doctor, you betrayed me. I trusted you. I even liked you, and all you

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace runs off. Gilmore comes down the stairs with a Sergeant.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant Smith.
Sir.
Attention! I'm placing you under close arrest under suspicion of offences contrary to the Official Secrets Act.
Yes, sir.
Scout seven reporting area two five zero nine clear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Imperial Daleks get ambushed by a pair of renegades. They are all lousy shots, but eventually an Imperial gets destroyed.

Dialogue.Line: Retreat! Squad Delta under attack from renegade Daleks. Retreat!
Mothership bridge to shuttle force controller. Receiving your signal.
We must recover the Hand of Omega without delay.
Shuttle force has encountered heavy resistance from renegade Daleks.
Order Special Weapons Dalek into position.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An even more heavily armoured Dalek with no vulnerable eyepiece and one big gun rolls down the road. It obliterates a grey Dalek with its first shot.
The Doctor uses a rope to lasso one of the shuttle's antenna. Gilmore ties the end off.

Dialogue.Line: Why are we doing this?

Elementary piracy, my dear Allison. Dalek shuttles have massive ground defences and an unguarded service hatch on top. Now once I'm down there, I'll attempt to open that hatch. Ace, you come after, then Gilmore, followed by Allison and Rachel. Any questions? No? Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses his umbrella to slide down the rope to the top of the shuttle. He kicks in the hatch.
The pilot Dalek is physically fastened to the controls through connections where its plunger and weapon ought to be.

Dialogue.Line: Emergency! Emergency! Unable to disengage from control position.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs some fibre optic cables from the control panel.

Dialogue.Line: Humans on the bridge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts his hat over its eyepiece.

Dialogue.Line: I'm not human.
You are the Doctor.
Yes.
You are the enemy of the Daleks.
Correct.
You must be exterminat

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek is switched off. The Doctor retrieves his hat.

Dialogue.Line: Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He closes the access hatch in the floor and goes to the open one.

Dialogue.Line: You can come down now!
Tea?
Yeah.
Come on, Sarge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mike attacks his guard and escapes.
Everyone is on board.

Dialogue.Line: What did you do to it?
I shorted it out. Daleks are such boring conversationalists.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor retrieves the Dalek's plunger from its storage box at its back.

Dialogue.Line: It's very functional.
Yes, they're not known for their aesthetic sense. Let's see what they were up to.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He uses the plunger to operate some controls. A star map lights up.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, the planet Skaro. So, the Daleks are returning to their ancestral seat. I think we've seen enough. Time to leave. Er, get off the grill.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He opens the floor hatch.

Dialogue.Line: We'll go back through the playground.
What about the massive ground defences?
Oh, I've turned those off. Come on, jump.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Allison jumps.
Mike enters the yard. The gates swing closed behind him to reveal two renegade Daleks.

Dialogue.Line: Exterminate. DALEK 2: Exterminate.
No, no, don't. Look, I have a message for Ratcliffe. Understand? A message for Mister Ratcliffe.
You are my prisoner. You will obey all instructions or you will be exterminated.
You said it, mate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Allison, Rachel, Gilmore, Ace and the Doctor exit the shuttlecraft. The hatch shuts on the Doctor's umbrella and he struggles to free it.

Dialogue.Line: I rigged the communications relay to the shuttle control system. We can monitor the Daleks on the transmat in the cellar.
You can't do that. You mashed up the transmat, remember?
I can do anything I like!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He finally pulls his umbrella free and stalks off.

Dialogue.Line: Kneel!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ratcliffe and Mike obey.

Dialogue.Line: Repairs on time controller almost complete.
Good.
(sotto) Without that thing, they're stuck here. Someone in possession of that would have something to bargain with.
For what, our lives?
Nothing so mundane. If we get that, we can demand anything.
You never give up, do you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The unfortunate Corporal who had been guarding Mike staggers upstairs.

Dialogue.Line: What happened?
Sergeant Smith.
Is he all right?
I've no idea, I'm a physicist.
He'll be fine. Rachel and Allison, I need your help.
Sorry?
He said he needed our help.
That's what I thought he said. Get your hands off his scalp and come on.
You all right, Corporal?
Sir.
Come with me. We'll search the building.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The girl carries the globe out.

Dialogue.Line: Time controller repaired and ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She places it next to the casket.

Dialogue.Line: Departure imminent.
Destroy human captives.
No!
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just then, the Imperial Special Weapon Dalek blasts the yard gates to splinters. The Dalek war begins.

Dialogue.Line: Now! Run!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ratcliffe grabs the time controller and runs up the exterior staircase after Mike.

Dialogue.Line: Recover the time controller.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The girl follows and zaps Ratcliffe with electricity from her hands. Mike grabs the time controller before he dies and gets inside. The girl follows. The Black Dalek withdraws to the store room and leaves the grey Daleks to fight it out with the Imperials and the Special Weapons Daleks. It is hardly a fair match.

Dialogue.Line: When he said he needed our help, I had hoped it meant more in a technical area.
It was a vain hope.
Ah, you brought it then. Put it down there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rachel and Allison put down the television they had struggled down the stairs with.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Doctor, will you please answer one question?
Yes?
Why are two Dalek factions fighting each other.
Ace.
It's simple, isn't it. Renegade Daleks are blobs.
Blobs?

Imperial Daleks are bionic blobs with bits added. You can tell that Daleks are into racial purity. So, one lot of Daleks reckon the other lot of blobs are too different. They're mutants. Not pure in their blobbiness.
Result?
They hate each other's chromosomes. War to the death.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor disentangles himself from the fibre optics of the transmat.

Dialogue.Line: Well, er, Ace, let's go and see which blobs are winning.
Doctor, how do you do that?
Do what?
How do you just rewire a piece of alien machinery?
It's easy when you have nine hundred years experience.
Force leader has recovered the Hand of Omega.
Excellent. Order all forces to make immediate withdrawal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Imperial Daleks leave Ratcliffe's yard, with the casket gliding behind them. Mike comes out of hiding and goes back down the staircase past Ratcliffe's body, carrying the time controller.
The Doctor and Ace have been hiding behind that gate again.

Dialogue.Line: It's Mike.
He's got the time controller. Typical human. You can always count on them to mess things up. Get after him. Stay with him. See where he's going.
Right.
Oh, Ace.
What?
No heroics. I've got enough problems already.
Trust me.
Prepare to place the Hand of Omega into the control circuit.
I obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The casket glides into the shuttlecraft.

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do after all this is over?
Retire to Cambridge and write my memoirs.
Professor!
Subject to security vetting, of course.
The shuttle seems to be leaving.
Good riddance to bad rubbish.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The shuttlecraft takes off with a lot less damage than when it landed. The Doctor stands next the Tardis and waves it goodbye. Ace also sees it fly away.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, wicked.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little girls skips along.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Doctor, are we out of the woods?
Provided everything goes according to my plan.
Plan?
I, er, I don't suppose you could let us know what your plan is?
It's a surprise.
Good. I love surprises.
Prepare for shuttle docking.
Lock the Hand of Omega into the control circuit.
Omega device is now locked in and running.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor plugs a camera and microphone into the television and transmat.

Dialogue.Line: How do I look? Don't answer. Do you mind? You're in my shot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He switches on the television set.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, hello, hello? Dalek mothership, come in please. Come in, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A grainy image of the Emperor Dalek appears on the television screen.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, there you are. This is the Doctor, President Elect of the High Council of Time Lords, Keeper of the legacy of Rassilon, Defender of the Laws of Time, Protector of Gallifrey. I call upon you to surrender the Hand of Omega and return to your customary time and place.
Ah, Doctor. You have changed again. Your appearance is as inconstant as your intelligence. You have confounded me for the last time!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Emperor's dome swings up to reveal -.

Dialogue.Line: Davros. I should have known. I see you've discarded the last vestige of your human form. Still no improvement.
Save your insults for the weak-minded, Doctor. DOCTOR [on screen]: Will you return the Hand of Omega or not?
Are you threatening me? If so, it is most unwise. DOCTOR [on screen]: Every time our paths have crossed, I have defeated you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Davros makes a gurgling sound that is supposed to be a laugh.

Dialogue.Line: You flatter yourself, Doctor. In the end, you are merely another Time Lord.
Oh, Davros, I am far more than just another Time Lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace lets herself in with the latch key and goes into the front room. Mike is waiting with a gun.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Ace.
Would you really shoot me?
If I had to.
You might have to.
Davros, the Hand of Omega is not to be trifled with.
I think I am quite capable of handling the technology. DOCTOR [on screen]: I sincerely doubt that.

Does it worry you, Doctor, that with it I will transform Skaro's sun into a source of unimaginable power? And with that power at my disposal, the Daleks shall sweep away Gallifrey and its impotent quorum of Time Lords!
The Daleks shall become Lords of Time! We shall become all

Powerful. Crush the lesser races. Conquer the galaxy. Unimaginable power. Unlimited rice pudding, et cetera, et cetera. DAVROS [on screen]: Do not anger me, Doctor. I can destroy you and this miserable, insignificant planet.
Oh, wonderful. What power, what brilliance. You can wipe out the odd civilisation, enslave the occasional culture, but it still won't detract from the basic fundamental truth of your own impotence!
Careful, Doctor.
(covers the microphone) Don't worry, I know what I'm doing.
I will teach you the folly of your words, Doctor. I will destroy you and demonstrate the power of the Daleks! DOCTOR [on screen]: Davros, I beg of you, don't use the Hand.
Ah, Doctor, now you begin to fear.
You're making a grave mistake.
Activate the Omega device!
Omega device activated.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A little star flies out of the Mothership.

Dialogue.Line: Plotting course to home planet Skaro.
Now the Daleks shall become the Lords of Time!
Entering Skaro time zone. First stage expansion. Primary neutrino release.
Core collapse instigated.
Danger! Instability! Reaction out of control.
No, this cannot be correct!
Home planet Skaro about to vapourise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Hand leaves the system as the star goes supernova and takes the planets with it.

Dialogue.Line: You have tricked me!
No, Davros. You tricked yourself.
Omega device returning.
Impact minus twenty five.
Do you think I would let you have control of the Hand of Omega?
Do not do this, I beg of you.
Nothing can stop it now.
Have pity on me.
I have pity for you.
Fifteen.
Goodbye, Davros. It hasn't been pleasant.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns off the transmission. Davros lowers the Emperor's dome and backs off the bridge.

Dialogue.Line: Emperor abandoning bridge.
Eight, seven
Emperor activating escape pod.
Four, three
Escape pod leaving mothership.
Two, one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Hand slams into the mothership. KaBOOM.

Dialogue.Line: What happened?
I programmed the Hand of Omega to fly into Skaro's sun and turn it supernova.
Super what?
He blew it up.
The resulting explosion destroyed Skaro, and the feedback destroyed the mothership. The Hand of Omega is now returning to Gallifrey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The doorbell rings.

Dialogue.Line: You stay there.
It might be the Doctor. Put the gun down, Mike. It's too late for that. Come on, Mike, who are you going to shoot with it, anyway?
Just stay there. (He goes and opens the front door. It is the little girl. She zaps him and he is thrown back onto the staircase, dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Black Dalek is in the street when the Doctor and Gilmore arrive in Red 4 from one direction, and the RAF lorry comes from the other.

Dialogue.Line: This is the last Dalek left. I'll call for reinforcements.
Not this time. I started this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets out of the van as the little girl enters the front room and smiles at Ace. He walks down the street towards the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Dalek, you have been defeated. Surrender. You have failed.
Insufficient data.
Your forces are destroyed. Your home planet a burnt cinder circling a dead sun.
There is no data.
Even Davros, your creator, is dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace ducks just in time for the little girl to miss her and smash the mirror instead.

Dialogue.Line: You have no superiors, no inferiors, no reinforcement, no hope, no rescue.
You are lying. There is insufficient data.
You're trapped a trillion miles and a thousand years from a disintegrated home.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Black Dalek starts twirling around, groaning.

Dialogue.Line: Out of control!
I have defeated you. You no longer serve any purpose.
Cannot compute. Unstable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little girl grabs her head and starts swinging back and forth, squealing.

Dialogue.Line: Unstable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Black Dalek atomises gently.
The little girl collapses. Ace comes out from behind the sofa to pick her up and hug her.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right. Don't worry. It's all over now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor prods the smoking remains of the Black Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Ashes to ashes, dust to dust.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The chapel bell tolls and an organ plays as a coffin is carried in for the service. Group Captain Gilmore escorts Mrs Smith, with Allison and Rachel behind. The Doctor stops Ace at the threshold.

Dialogue.Line: Time to leave.
Yes. Doctor?
Yes?
We did good, didn't we?
Perhaps. Time will tell. It always does.
